question: If <katex>$y=\frac{\cos x}{1+\sin x}$</katex> then
a) <katex>$\frac{dy}{dx}=\frac{-1}{1+\sin x}$</katex>
b) <katex>$\frac{dy}{dx}=\frac{1}{1+\sin x}$</katex>
c) <katex>$\frac{dy}{dx}=-\frac{1}{2}\sec^{2}(\frac{\pi}{4}-\frac{x}{2})$</katex>
d) <katex>$\frac{dy}{dx}=\frac{1}{2}\sec^{2}(\frac{\pi}{4}-\frac{x}{2})$</katex>
choices: Both a and c are correct
Both b and d are correct
explanation: Method 1: Quotient rule. <katex>$y' = \frac{-\sin x(1+\sin x) - \cos x(\cos x)}{(1+\sin x)^2} = \frac{-\sin x - \sin^2 x - \cos^2 x}{(1+\sin x)^2} = \frac{-(1+\sin x)}{(1+\sin x)^2} = \frac{-1}{1+\sin x}$</katex>. So (a) is correct.
